{"title":"Section 2, Page 12","subjec":{},"descri":{},"creato":{},"publis":{},"date":{},"year":{},"format":{},"reposi":{},"collec":{},"reposa":{},"rights":{},"digitb":{},"langua":{},"topics":{},"cite":{},"notes":{},"notesa":{},"source":{},"box":{},"folder":{},"identi":{},"relati":{},"findin":{},"catalo":{},"type":{},"full":"12
I have purposely employed plain, simple and strong terms,
because, I desire to manifest our plain, simple and strong
determination. I believe that, if we will it firmly, it will be
accomplished, surely and speedily!
With regard to the other portion of this first resolution,
viz : "From New Orleans to Washington, in St. Landry," it
is obvious that a resolution only declaring that A Railroad
shall be built, would be too vague and meaningless. Sonnl
termini must be stated, in order to define the road to which
we allude. I have named those which seemed to me best,
but in this, and in all, (as I said before,) I do not desire to dic-|
tate. If any gentleman will propose better termini, I will relinquish mine and adopt his, submitting myself cheerfully to
the decision of my co-delegates.
The second resolution is, that a committee to be called "The
Permanent Committee on the Opelousas, Attakapas and New
Orleans Railroad." bo appointed by the President of this
Convention, whose numbers shall consist of---
Now, conventions and resolutions alone cannot build a
road—you must have working men to carry out your resolves
when you have adjourned. My impression is that such a committee as is here proposed, and as our able President will,
with his usual good judgment, appoint, would be, (when he
is added to it, as I hope he will be) a working one. It would
prove an immense saving of time. While we are waiting
for such State Legislation as may be needed, this Committee could procure surveys of the route and estimates of the
costs of construction. It would frame a provisional charted
and take the necessary steps to procure the requisite legislation to confirm it. It would procure the funds needed for
preliminary expenses. Thus, as soon as the company shall
be organized, it will find itself furnished with the material
for immediate action.
